oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Double wedding ring quilt
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Double Wedding Ring pattern quilt, hanging on a clothes line. The quilt has a flower motif quilted inside each ring and is finished with a scalloped edge binding technique. The quilt belonged to Belle and Clyde Williams, a brother and sister from

While there is much myth surrounding the origins of the Double Wedding Ring pattern, its earliest known publication was in 1928 in Capper's Weekly, a newspaper published by Arthur Capper in Topeka, Kansas. According to folk tradition, if a couple; received this quilt as a gift and slept under it, their marriage would be long and happy. Another bit of folklore implies that if a single girl makes a Double Wedding Ring and gives it to the gentleman of her choosing he will soon be her husband.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project Collection, 1979-1984
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Quilts; Double wedding ring quilts; Quilts--United States--History--20th century; Quiltmakers -- United States; Folk art --United States
